name: Lars Valerian Ahlfors
motivation: for research on covering surfaces related to Riemann surfaces of inverse functions of entire and meromorphic functions. Opened up a new fileds of analysis.

name: Sir Michael Francis Atiyah
motivation: Did joint work with Hirzebruch in K-theory; proved jointly with Singer the index theorem of elliptic operators on complex manifolds; worked in collaboration with Bott to prove a fixed point theorem related to the "Lefschetz formula".

name: Artur Ávila
motivation: For his profound contributions to dynamical systems theory, which have changed the face of the field, using the powerful idea of renormalization as a unifying principle.

name: Alan Baker
motivation: Generalized the Gelfond-Schneider theorem (the solution to Hilbert's seventh problem). From this work he generated transcendental numbers not previously identified.

name: Manjul Bhargava
motivation: For developing new methods in the geometry of numbers, which he applied to count rings of small rank and to bound the average rank of elliptic curves.

name: Caucher Birkar
motivation: For his proof of the boundedness of Fano varieties and for contributions to the minimal model program.

name: Enrico Bombieri
motivation: For his major contributions in the primes, in univalent functions and the local Bieberbach conjecture, in theory of functions of several complex variables, and in theory of partial differential equations and minimal surfaces – in particular, to the solution of Sergei Bernstein’s problem in higher dimensions.

name: Richard Borcherds
motivation: For his work on the introduction of vertex algebras, the proof of the Moonshine conjecture and for his discovery of a new class of automorphic infinite products.

name: Jean Bourgain
motivation: For spectacular inroads into several central topics of mathematical analysis: the geometry of Banach spaces, convexity in high dimensions, harmonic analysis, ergodic theory, and nonlinear partial differential equations from mathematical physics; doing this in all of these fields by simultaneously bringing into play different areas of mathematics: number theory, combinatorics and probability, and showing their relevance to the problem in a previously unforeseen fashion.

name: Paul Joseph Cohen
motivation: For his proof of the independence of the continuum hypothesis from the other axioms of set theory.

name: Alain Connes
motivation: Contributed to the theory of operator algebras, particularly the general classification and structure theorem of factors of type III, classification of automorphisms of the hyperfinite factor, classification of injective factors and applications of the theory of C*-algebras to foliations and differential geometry in general.

name: Pierre Deligne
motivation: For providing a solution of the three Weil conjectures concerning generalizations of the Riemann hypothesis to finite fields. His work did much to unify algebraic geometry and algebraic number theory.

name: Simon Donaldson
motivation: For his work on the topology of four-manifolds, especially for showing that there is a differential structure on euclidian four-space which is different from the usual structure.

name: Jesse Douglas
motivation: For solving the Plateau problem.

name: Vladimir Drinfeld
birth_place: Kharkiv, Ukrainian SSR, Soviet Union (today Ukraine)
motivation: For his work on quantum groups and for his work in number theory.

name: Gerd Faltings
motivation: For proving the Mordell Conjecture, using methods of arithmetic algebraic geometry.

name: Charles Louis Fefferman
motivation: For contributing several innovations that revised the study of multidimensional complex analysis by finding correct generalizations of classical (low-dimensional) results.

name: Alessio Figalli
motivation: For contributions to the theory of optimal transport and its applications in partial differential equations, metric geometry and probability.

name: Michael Freedman
motivation: For developing new methods for topological analysis of four-manifolds. One of his results is a proof of the four-dimensional Poincaré conjecture.

name: Sir William Timothy Gowers
motivation: For his contributions to functional analysis and combinatorics, developing a new vision of infinite-dimensional geometry, including the solution of two of Stefan Banach’s problems and the discovery of the so called Gowers’ dichotomy: every infinite dimensional Banach space contains either a subspace with many symmetries (technically, with an unconditional basis) or a subspace, on which every operator is a Fredholm operator of index zero.

name: Alexander Grothendieck
motivation: Built on work of Weil and Zariski and effected fundamental advances in algebraic geometry. He introduced the idea of K-theory (the Grothendieck groups and rings). Revolutionized homological algebra in his celebrated "Tohoku paper".

name: Martin Hairer
motivation: For his outstanding contributions to the theory of stochastic partial differential equations, and in particular for the creation of a theory of regularity structures for such equations.

name: Heisuke Hironaka
motivation: For his work in algebraic geometry, including the resolution of certain singularities and torus imbeddings with implications in the theory of analytic functions, and complex and Kähler manifolds.

name: Lars Hörmander
motivation: For his work on partial differential equations.

name: Sir Vaughan F. R. Jones
motivation: For discovering an astonishing relationship between von Neumann algebras and geometric topology and, as a result, finding a new polynomial invariant for knots and links in 3-space. The central connecting link in all this mathematics is a tower of nested algebras which he had discovered earlier in the course of proving the Index Theorem for von Neumann algebras

name: Kunihiko Kodaira
motivation: For his work in algebraic geometry and complex analysis.

name: Maxim Lvovich Kontsevich
motivation: For his contributions to algebraic geometry, topology, and mathematical physics, including the proof of Edward Witten’s conjecture of intersection numbers in moduli spaces of stable curves, construction of the universal Vassiliev invariant of knots, and formal quantization of Poisson manifolds.

name: Laurent Lafforgue
motivation: For his work connecting number theory and analysis.

name: Elon Lindenstrauss
motivation: For his results in the area of measure rigidity in ergodic theory, and their applications to number theory.

name: Pierre-Louis Lions
motivation: For the development of important techniques for the unified treatment and solution of large classes of nonlinear partial differential equations, such as the Boltzmann equation and similar transport equations, and for contributions to several classes of variational problems and the "viscosity method".

name: Gregory Margulis
motivation: For providing innovative analysis of the structure of Lie groups. His work has had an impact on combinatorics, differential geometry, ergodic theory, dynamical systems, and Lie groups.

name: Curtis T. McMullen
motivation: For his contributions to the theory of holomorphic dynamics and the geometrization of three-manifolds, including proofs of Ber’s conjecture on the density of cusp points in the boundary of the Teichmüller space, and Irwin Kra’s theta-function conjecture.

name: John Willard Milnor
motivation: For proving that a 7-dimensional sphere can have several differential structures, which led to the creation of th e field of differential topology.

name: Maryam Mirzakhani
motivation: For her work on complex geometry and dynamical systems.

name: Shigefumi Mori
motivation: For important developments in algebraic geometry: the Minimal Model Program or Mori’s Program, in connection with the classification problems of algebraic varieties of dimension three.

name: David Mumford
motivation: For his attack on problems of the existence and structure of varieties of moduli, i.e. varieties whose points parametrize isomorphism classes of some type of geometric object. He also made several important contributions to the theory of algebraic surfaces.

name: Bảo Châu Ngô
motivation: For his proof of the Fundamental Lemma in the theory of automorphic forms through the introduction of new algebro-geometric methods.

name: Sergei Novikov
birth_place: Gorky (today Nizhny Novgorod), Soviet Union (today Russia)
motivation: For important advances in topology, the most well-known being his proof of the topological invariance of the Pontrjagin classes of the differentiable manifold, including a study of the cohomology and homotopy of Thom spaces.

name: Andrei Okounkov
motivation: For his contributions bridging probability, representation theory and algebraic geometry.

name: Grigori Yakovlevich Perelman
birth_place: Leningrad (today Saint Petersburg), Soviet Union (today Russia)
motivation: For his contributions to geometry and his revolutionary insights into the analytical and geometric structure of the Ricci flow.

name: Daniel G. Quillen
motivation: The prime architect of the higher algebraic K-theory, a new tool that successfully employed geometric and topological methods and ideas to formulate and solve major problems in algebra, particularly ring theory and module theory.

name: Klaus Friedrich Roth
motivation: For his work in number theory.

name: Peter Scholze
motivation: For transforming arithmetic algebraic geometry over p-adic fields through his introduction of perfectoid spaces, with application to Galois representations, and for the development of new cohomology theories.

name: Laurent Schwartz
motivation: For his work in functional analysis.

name: Atle Selberg
motivation: For his work in number theory.

name: Jean-Pierre Serre
motivation: For achieving major results on the homotopy groups of spheres, especially through the use of the method of spectral sequences. He also reformulated and extended some of the main results of complex variable theory in terms of sheaves.

name: Stephen Smale
motivation: For proving the generalized Poincaré conjecture in dimension n>=5: Every closed n-dimensional manifold homotopy-equivalent to the n-dimensional sphere is homeomorphic to it. Introduced the method of handle-bodies to solve this and related problems.

name: Stanislav Smirnov
birth_place: Leningrad (today Saint Petersburg), Soviet Union (today Russia)
motivation: For the proof of conformal invariance of percolation and the planar Ising model in statistical physics.

name: Terence Tao
motivation: For his contributions to partial differential equations, combinatorics, harmonic analysis and additive number theory.

name: René Thom
motivation: For his work in topology.

name: John Griggs Thompson
motivation: For proving, together with Walter Feit, that all non-cyclic finite simple groups have even order. The extension of this work by Thompson determined the minimal simple finite groups, i.e. the simple finite groups whose proper subgroups are solvable.

name: William P. Thurston
motivation: For his work in topology.

name: Akshay Venkatesh
motivation: For his synthesis of analytic number theory, homogeneous dynamics, topology, and representation theory, which has resolved long-standing problems in areas such as the equidistribution of arithmetic objects.

name: Cédric Villani
motivation: For his proofs of nonlinear Landau damping and convergence to equilibrium for the Boltzmann equation.

name: Vladimir Voevodsky
motivation: For developing new cohomology theories for algebraic varieties, one important consequence being his solution of the Milnor Conjecture – an outstanding problem in algebraic K-theory.

name: Wendelin Werner
motivation: For his contributions to the development of stochastic Loewner evolution, the geometry of two-dimensional Brownian motion, and conformal field theory.

name: Edward Witten
motivation: For demonstrating that the Jones invariant of knots could be computed as the statistical average value of an operator representing parallel transport around the knot, with the statistical weight given by a particular gauge theory action.

name: Shing-Tung Yau
motivation: For making contributions in differential equations, also to the Calabi conjecture in algebraic geometry, to the positive mass conjecture of general relativity theory, and to real and complex Monge-Ampère equations.

name: Jean-Christophe Yoccoz
motivation: For his fundamental work in Dynamical Systems, especially in the theory of circle maps and the theory of smooth centralizers of diffeomorphisms, as well as his groundbreaking contribution to the MLC (Mandelbrot Local Connectivity) conjecture.

name: Efim Zelmanov
motivation: For the solution of the restricted Burnside problem in group theory.
